docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your Feb. 25 editorial ''Toward a Sensible Homeless Policy'' is correct in saying homeless people need social service supports to live independently and to gain job skills -- but you do not go far enough. As a coalition of more than 1,000 soup kitchens and food pantries, we have seen these fragile programs, originally started to provide emergency help, become the front-line social service system for more than half a million New Yorkers. And the breadlines continue to grow.

headline.main: A Support System For the Homeless

docs.abstract: Judith Walker letter on Feb 25 editorial Toward a Sensible Homeless Policy

docs.lead_paragraph: Often, when a patient raises breast cancer treatment options with a physician (''Breast Cancer in Blacks''), she gets the answer that some of these tests, drugs and procedures are expensive, and/or insurance companies will not cover them because they are not currently recognized as ''standard of care.''
docs.abstract: F Gina Gelb letter on insurance coverage for women being treated for breast cancer

docs.lead_paragraph: It is not the future that worries Rolf-Ernst Breuer, chairman of Deutsche Bank. It is the present. As chairman of one of the world's biggest banks, Mr. Breuer is convinced that the World Wide Web will eviscerate traditional banking -- but also open huge new opportunities.

headline.main: Streamlining A German Blimp; Deutsche Bank Strains to Be Nimble in a Modern Market

docs.abstract: Deutsch Bank chairman Rolf-Ernst Breuer is considering giving up controlling stake in his own branches; Deutsche Bank has 1,500 local offices and 7 million retail banking customers; it has biggest branch network in Germany, but network barely ekes out profit and consistently drags down bank's overall performance; Germany has far too many banks partly because it has huge sector of nonprofit savings banks owned by state and local governments, which keep margins low; having separated Deutsche Bank's retail network into stand-alone company, called Deutsche Bank 24, Breuer has pleaded in vain for rivals to buy in as minority partners; few analysts say Deutsche Bank will sell off its branch network; but Breuer is clearly impatient and also seems convinced that traditional banking is withering and radical changes are necessary to survive; graphs; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In all the hyperbole of political campaigns, it is rare that a candidate gets quick, tangible results, but Vice President Al Gore seems to have done it, persuading the nation's biggest health insurance company to show more generosity to one of its subscribers. Within 24 hours of Mr. Gore's appeal to the company, Aetna Inc., to continue coverage for a 6-month-old baby born with severe brain damage, the company agreed to do so, reversing an earlier decision.

headline.main: Gore's Intervention Restores Care for Ill Baby

docs.abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore campaigns in Denver, Colo; his successful efforts in winning health coverage from Aetna Inc for brain damaged baby while campaigning in Seattle, Wash, noted (M)
